41 Mosiah 16:5

42 Doctrine and Covenants 88:6

43 Alma 36:13-15

44 See 2 Nephi 4:17-19

45 See Alma 5:14

46 Doctrine and Covenants 58:42:43

47 See Doctrine and Covenants 45:3-5

48 See Alma 27:24-26

49 Mosiah 5:2

50 Elder D. Todd Christofferson, BYU-Idaho 27 January 2009, Devotional Address

51 http://www.lds.org/general-conference/2009/10/repent-that-i-may-heal-you?lang=eng,

52 Mosiah 3:17



http://www.byui.edu/Presentations/Transcripts/Devotionals/2012_07_10_Clark.htm

 

 

 

 

My dear brothers and sisters, I am so very pleased to be with you today. I always appreciate the prayers of those who open our devotionals, and especially today, I am particularly in need of your prayers today. The music is always so inspiring, those that perform always sound as if there is a choir of angels singing.

 

From the time construction started in 2006 on this facility I have stood in this location many times looking out over this area that is now finished. I imagined how wonderful the day would be when the project would be complete; when students, faculty, and staff would gather for devotional and other great events to be held in this facility. It has been exciting to be involved with the construction of this facility, to attend the dedication of this facility, and to come to devotionals over the past 18 months, but for some reason it is not as exciting for me today.

 

Brothers and sisters, the topic that I have chosen to speak on today is the power of prayer. I will always be grateful to my mother––who is with us today––for teaching me as young child to pray; not only to pray, but to pray daily. Prayer was always a priority in our home as I was growing up.  My parents always ensured that we gathered for family prayer everyday. Many of the things that were included our family prayer were gratitude for the gospel, family, and the ability to work and provide for our needs.

 

My first day on the job at BYU-Idaho, which at that time was Ricks College, Chuck Frost introduced me to my staff and called on one to offer a prayer to start our meeting. Having worked in the corporate sector for many years prior to coming to BYU-Idaho, I was pleasantly surprised to know that meetings start and end with prayer at this great institution. Brothers and sisters, it may seem foreign to think that we pray about design and construction projects, facilities management issues, security and safety issues, and what the campus may need as part of its physical makeup, but it is wonderful to know all things on this campus are directed by the Lord through many prayers in all areas of this institution.  

 

There is truly power in prayer. The Savior instructed the Nephites to watch and pray always. This instruction is for our benefit today also. 3 Nephi 18:18-21 gives us instruction, a warning, and a beautiful promise:

 

“Behold, verily, verily, I say unto you, ye must watch and pray always lest ye enter into temptation; for Satan desireth to have you, that he may sift you as wheat.

 

“Therefore ye must always pray unto the Father in my name;

 

“And whatsoever ye shall ask the Father in my name, which is right, believing that ye shall receive, behold it shall be given unto you.

 

“Pray in your families unto the Father, always in my name, that your wives and your children may be blessed.”

 

The instruction given is as follows:

 

 

The warning given is:

 

 

The promises given are as follows:

 

 

Over the years as we have raised our family, I have found great comfort in these scriptures. Verse 21 instructs us “Pray in your families unto the Father, always in my name, that your wives and your children may be blessed.” One of our family members was struggling in their teenage years. I was very concerned and looking for direction. I remember clearly pondering this concern one night while I was driving home from work. I decided to call my parents for some counsel and advice. I asked them, “What did you do when I was struggling in my teenage years?” I was surprised by the answer, “The only thing we could do: we prayed for you.” I am so grateful for their prayers, and as we have talked with our children they have expressed their appreciation for our prayers for them.

 

Many of you are pondering starting a family or are in the early stages of beginning your families. Please read 3 Nephi 18:18-21 and consider the instruction given as you start this next phase of your life. There is great instruction given and great blessings promised in these verses.

 

The book of Alma has so many great examples of instruction to us about prayer, faith, fasting, and the purpose of the Atonement. Alma teaches us mightily about faith and prayer. I love Alma and I love his instruction to us. In chapter 37 as Alma was turning the plates over to his son Helaman to keep a record of his people, Alma gave Helaman great instruction in verse 21. Alma counsels Helaman to be diligent in keeping the commandments as they are written. If we are faithful in keeping the commandments with diligence, we have prepared ourselves to hear the word of the Lord when he instructs us as we pray. Alma again instructs Helaman to keep the commandments in verse 35. Then in verse 36 and 37, Alma instructs Helaman to pray for his support in all things.

 

“O, remember, my son, and learn wisdom in thy youth; yea, learn in thy youth to keep the commandments of God.

 

“Yea, and cry unto God for all thy support; yea, let all thy doings be unto the Lord, and whithersoever thou goest let it be in the Lord; yea, let all thy thoughts be directed unto the Lord; yea, let the affections of thy heart be placed upon the Lord forever.

 

“Counsel with the Lord in all thy doings, and he will direct thee for good; yea, when thou liest down at night lie down unto the Lord, that he may watch over you in your sleep; and when thou risest in the morning let thy heart be full of thanks unto God; and if ye do these things, ye shall be lifted up at the last day.”

 

The promise given in verse 37 gives us great hope “and if ye do these things, ye shall be lifted up at the last day.” Brothers and sisters, as you continue in your education do as we are instructed in these verses. 

 

 

Be prayerful and listen carefully as you apply for employment and make critical decisions for your family. If you pray for guidance at this time of your life, the Lord will guide you in all things that are necessary for your wellbeing.

 

In Alma 34:17-29, Amulek teaches us that the eternal plan of redemption is based on faith and repentance and that we need to pray for temporal and spiritual blessings. He gives us great instruction that we need to be humble and continue to pray. We are also instructed what to pray for, how and where we should pray, for whom we should pray, and what we need to do once we have prayed. Please listen to these verses of scripture and ponder the instruction given.

 

“Therefore may God grant unto you, my brethren, that ye may begin to exercise your faith unto repentance, that ye begin to call upon his holy name, that he would have mercy upon you;

 

“Yea, cry unto him for mercy; for he is mighty to save.

 

“Yea, humble yourselves, and continue in prayer unto him.

 

“Cry unto him when ye are in your fields, yea, over all your flocks.

 

“Cry unto him in your houses, yea, over all your household, both morning, mid-day, and evening.

 

“Yea, cry unto him against the power of your enemies.

 

“Yea, cry unto him against the devil, who is an enemy to all righteousness.

 

“Cry unto him over the crops of your fields, that ye may prosper in them.

 

“Cry over the flocks of your fields, that they may increase.

 

“But this is not all; ye must pour out your souls in your closets, and your secret places, and in your wilderness.

 

“Yea, and when you do not cry unto the Lord, let your hearts be full, drawn out in prayer unto him continually for your welfare, and also for the welfare of those who are around you.

 

“And now behold, my beloved brethren, I say unto you, do not suppose that this is all; for after ye have done all these things, if ye turn away the needy, and the naked, and visit not the sick and afflicted, and impart of your substance, if ye have, to those who stand in need—I say unto you, if ye do not any of these things, behold, your prayer is vain, and availeth you nothing, and ye are as hypocrites who do deny the faith.

 

“Therefore, if ye do not remember to be charitable, ye are as dross, which the refiners do cast out, (it being of no worth) and is trodden under foot of men.”

 

My father was an example in his life and my mother still is an example of these scriptures to our family. They always prayed as instructed in these scriptures. They have always prayed for our family. They prayed that their business would prosper so they could provide for their family and they have always been charitable to those in need. They have been a great example of these principles to our family.

 

I hope that each one of us can be humble, continue in prayer, cry unto the Lord in our homes, morning, midday, and evening, for our welfare, and also for the welfare of those who are around us. The Lord knows each one of us personally. He is very mindful of our needs. He will hear and answer our prayers if we remember to ask in our times of need. Even when we ask for the simplest things, he will hear our prayers.

 

Years ago, when I was a Young Men president, there was a family that lived near our home with a son who was struggling. I had the opportunity to invite this young man to go boating with us. We spent several hours on the lake that day and we skied until the sun went down that evening. The boat ramp was several miles from where we were skiing and we were running low on gas. The night was very dark. We were using a spot light to find our way back to the boat ramp when the boat ran out of gas. The first thing that came to mind was it is going to be a very long night on this lake. As we talked about our options that were very limited we decided to pray for help.

 

We finished the prayer then sat quietly in the boat. After a short period of time that seemed long that night, we heard the sound of a small fishing boat coming toward us. We used our spotlight to get the fisherman’s attention. We explained our situation and he offered to go the boat ramp to get a five-gallon can of gas he had in his truck. The Lord was mindful of our needs that night and our prayers were answered along with an opportunity to teach this young man and some of our family members the power of prayer.

 

The Lord hears the simplest prayers. The gospel was restored because of the faith of Joseph Smith and his sincere prayer at age 14 after he had read James 1:5: “If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him.”

 

There is a great promise in this scripture. If we will simply ask in faith for those things that are right it shall be given. I am sure many here today can tell a story of how a simple and sincere prayer was answered. Many years ago in Adelaide, Australia, a young mother, Sister Pat Hedger, was widowed at the age of 28––left to raise 3 young children. Pat was employed as an office assistant for the South Australia Police Department and was struggling with the death of her husband. A lady in the office knew of Pat’s situation. She asked Pat if she had ever prayed for help. Pat had grown up in a home that was not necessarily active in their religion and had never learned to pray. Pat’s friend taught her how to offer a simple prayer and to ask for comfort. Pat found comfort in prayer. A simple prayer softened her heart and prepared her to accept the gospel. 

 

About eight years after Pat had learned to pray, my companion and I knocked on her door. She was busy, so we left her a copy of the Book of Mormon and set up a return appointment. When we returned to teach Pat she related her story to us. As we taught her the first discussion, we shared the Joseph Smith story with her and she related her personal experience with prayer. We asked Pat if she would offer a prayer before we left her home that night. She accepted and offered a very simple but sincere prayer. We set another appointment for the following evening to share the plan of salvation. Because of that simple prayer she offered years before she was prepared to recognize the truth of the Book of Mormon, she was baptized a week later. Pat’s two sons were baptized the following month and her daughter was baptized several months later.

 

Because of a simple prayer, a family was prepared to accept the gospel. Since that time Pat served in many callings, her sons Brenton and Darrell served missions, and her daughter Julie has served in the Young Women and many other callings faithfully. About seven years ago I received an email from Pat’s son, Brenton. He had just been called to serve as a bishop and now serves on the Adelaide North Stake High Council. Through a simple prayer a young family was prepared to hear and accept the gospel and now has the opportunity for eternal life. The Hedger family continues to serve and loves the Lord because of a mother’s simple prayer in a time of need.

 

At the dedication of the Kirtland Temple the Lord gave the Saints great instruction about prayer and fasting. Although the Lord was talking about his temple in these scriptures, we can learn a great lesson of how we should establish our homes as place of prayer and fasting.

 

“And as all have not faith, seek ye diligently and teach one another words of wisdom; yea, seek ye out of the best books words of wisdom, seek learning even by study and also by faith;

 

“Organize yourselves; prepare every needful thing, and establish a house, even a house of prayer, a house of fasting, a house of faith, a house of learning, a house of glory, a house of order, a house of God;

 

“That your incomings may be in the name of the Lord, that your outgoings may be in the name of the Lord, that all your salutations may be in the name of the Lord, with uplifted hands unto the Most High” (D&C 109: 7-8).

 

This instruction sounds familiar doesn’t it? The Learning Model is such a great example of the principles taught in these scriptures of how we should approach many things in our lives.

 

 

Alma and the sons of Mosiah had a great understanding of these principles and how we are to prepare ourselves to be servants of the Lord, prepare ourselves for our careers, prepare ourselves to lead our families, and have great success in the gospel.

 

“And now it came to pass that as Alma was journeying from the land of Gideon southward, away to the land of Manti, behold, to his astonishment, he met with the sons of Mosiah journeying towards the land of Zarahemla.

 

“Now these sons of Mosiah were with Alma at the time the angel first appeared unto him; therefore Alma did rejoice exceedingly to see his brethren; and what added more to his joy, they were still his brethren in the Lord; yea, and they had waxed strong in the knowledge of the truth; for they were men of a sound understanding and they had searched the scriptures diligently, that they might know the word of God.

 

“But this is not all; they had given themselves to much prayer, and fasting; therefore they had the spirit of prophecy, and the spirit of revelation, and when they taught, they taught with power and authority of God” (Alma 17:1-3).

 

My wonderful wife and I have taken the opportunity many times throughout our marriage to call upon the Lord for special help through prayer and fasting––when our sons were serving in the mission field, when our daughter has come up against challenges, when our extended families have had challenges.

 

We had a great opportunity in our home to participate in special time of prayer and fasting with our children 11 years ago as my older brother was fighting for his life. He had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and if any of you know about this type of cancer, it is normally fatal. We invited our children to participate in a full fast for my brother. I am not sure, but I believe this was the first time all of our children together had participated in a full 24-hour fast as a family.

 

We opened this fast together as a family with a very sincere prayer in behalf of my brother. This fast has been an anchor in our family as to the power of prayer and fasting and has helped strengthen the faith of our entire family. Today my brother is still alive and is doing well. We consider this a miracle provided to our family through faith, prayer, and fasting. The Lord is very aware of each of us individually. He hears and answers our prayers as we ask in faith, and in his name. Ensure as you establish your home and family that you do as we are instructed in Doctrine and Covenants and in Alma. I have a strong testimony of how the Lord will bless us as we ask in faith, prayer, and fasting.

 

While serving as President of BYU-Idaho, Elder David A. Bednar was invited to speak at a devotional at BYU. His topic was the Atonement and the Journey of Mortality. This talk was printed in the Ensign this past April and I would highly recommend you review it. Elder Bednar stated, “The journey of mortality is to go from bad to good to better and to have our very natures changed.” Elder Bednar noted the Book of Mormon has many examples of those who were transformed by the enabling power of the Atonement through prayer. As members of the Church we are generally familiar with the cleansing power of the Atonement, but Elder Bednar teaches us so eloquently about the enabling power of the Atonement through prayer. One example he shared was how Nephi understood the enabling power of the Savior:

 

“Nephi is an example of one who knew, understood, and relied upon the enabling power of the Savior. Recall that the sons of Lehi had returned to Jerusalem to enlist Ishmael and his household in their cause. Laman and others in the party traveling with Nephi from Jerusalem back to the wilderness rebelled, and Nephi exhorted his brethren to have faith in the Lord. It was at this point in their journey that Nephi’s brothers bound him with cords and planned his destruction. Please note Nephi’s prayer: ‘O Lord, according to my faith which is in thee, wilt thou deliver me from the hands of my brethren; yea, even give me strength that I may burst these bands with which I am bound’ (1 Nephi 7:17; emphasis added).

 

“Do you know what I likely would have prayed for if I had been tied up by my brothers? ‘Please get me out of this mess NOW!’ It is especially interesting to me that Nephi did not pray to have his circumstances changed. Rather, he prayed for the strength to change his circumstances. And I believe he prayed in this manner precisely because he knew, understood, and had experienced the enabling power of the Atonement.”

 

Elder Bednar helped me better understand that we should not ask the Lord to fix our problems, but ask for the Lord’s help to change our circumstances through faith and obedience to the commandments. Elder Bednar has given great instruction in the following quote:

 

“The implication of this episode for each of us is straightforward. As you and I come to understand and employ the enabling power of the Atonement in our personal lives, we will pray and seek for strength to change our circumstances rather than praying for our circumstances to be changed. We will become agents who act rather than objects that are acted upon.”

 

Brothers and sisters, it is my prayer that as you go forward from this university you will better understand the importance of a strong relationship with your Savior through prayer. Take time each day, morning and night, to pray to your Heavenly Father, have a prayer in your heart throughout the day, and be obedient in all things so that the Lord may bless you. Pray for help in your education, and for assistance in taking care of your personal needs. As you establish families, pray for the Lord’s continued help in providing for them, and as we are taught in 3 Nephi 18, pray in your families unto the Father, in the name of Christ, that your wives and your children may be blessed.

 

It is my sincere testimony that there is great power in prayer. I have seen and continue to see great blessing poured out upon our family because of faith, prayer, and fasting. The Lord loves each of you and is waiting to pour his blessing upon you as you are faithful and obedient. This is my testimony and I leave this with you in the name of Jesus Christ, amen.



http://www.byui.edu/Presentations/Transcripts/Graduation/2012_07_20_Clarke.htm

 

 

 

 

I am honored to be here this evening and express appreciation for this wonderful assignment. I bring you the love and congratulations of President Monson, the First Presidency, and the Quorum of the Twelve. You are blessed to have President Kim Clark as president of this great institution. No, he is not a relative. My reputation would improve if he was. He is a great man with much experience to share with you, and I hope you have learned a great deal from him.

 

Mary Anne and I lived in Guatemala for five years. Elder Richard G. Scott visited while we were there and we toured El Salvador and Panama. On a Friday evening we had a devotional in Panama. We arrived about 6:30 pm and the devotional was scheduled for 7:00 pm. As we were entering the building and walking down the corridor, I looked into one of the classrooms and a little boy was on his knees praying.  I felt that I was on sacred ground and I shut the door. We went on to the Chapel and shortly thereafter the little boy entered and sat behind us. We had a wonderful devotional with Elder Scott, and as the devotional ended I approached the little boy.

 

This was our conversation:

 

“What is your name?”

“My name is Carlos Pitti.”

“How old are you?”

“Thirteen years old.”

             “Are you here with your parents?”

             “No, I am here with my brother.”

             “Why were you praying in the classroom?”

             “I was praying that I would feel the spirit during the devotional.”

             “Did you feel the spirit?”

 

As tears ran down his cheeks from his big brown eyes, he said, “Yes, I did.”

 

I hope and pray that like Carlos, you have prayed that you will feel the spirit during our time together. The Holy Ghost will teach you if you have come prepared, like my friend Carlos.

 

Being in Rexburg is like being home. I grew up on Center Street, one half block from BYU-Idaho. In those days there were only three buildings, the Kirkham Auditorium and two old rock buildings, which have long since been torn down. There was only a field of sagebrush and we chased rabbits where most of the buildings are today.

 

I even remember when Ricks College, now BYU-Idaho, was so small that they were thinking of moving the college to another location! We were thrilled to have it remain close to our home on Center Street! Oh how the campus has changed. 

 

I attended Ricks College and graduated, then went on to BYU and Washington State University where I received my MBA. It was in Rexburg that I was instructed and influenced by my parents, my blind grandfather, Alma Benjamin Larsen, who was a patriarch, family, friends, teachers, and leaders. It was on this hill that I saw the prophet of God in person for the first time, President David O. McKay. When I saw him I knew he was a prophet. There are so many memories. For me life all started here in Rexburg. For you, in a way, it will start here. You have been influenced by friends, professors, leaders, and many others. For you and me, I would like to express our appreciation for their great influence.

 

Today is about you and your future. Don’t look at today as the end, but look at it as the beginning. I have looked at the information about you. You are all different, but in a more important way, you are the same. You are children of God with divine potential to become all you ever dreamed you could be.  What you have and will become is more important than what you learned here at BYU-Idaho. You have been preparing to be disciples of the Savior and leaders in your home, the Church, and the world.

 

This evening I would like to talk about the law of the harvest that can help you fulfill your dreams.

In Galatians, we are taught the law of the harvest:

 

“Be not deceived; God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap.” 1

 

William George Jordan in the book “The Kingship of Self-Control,” said it this way:

 

“Man has two creators–his god and himself. His first creator furnishes him the raw material of his life and the laws in conformity with which he can make that life what he will. His second creator, himself, has marvelous powers he rarely realizes. It is what a man makes of himself that counts.” 2

 

If we don’t plant good seeds, we cannot expect a bountiful harvest. If you decide now to be the best you can be, in all that you do, and reach for the stars, so to speak, your harvest will be plentiful indeed. As you begin on this part of life’s journey I would like to talk about five seeds that if planted and nourished will provide a bountiful harvest.

 

The First Seed is Learning to Love Work

 

Nephi learned at a very young age the importance of work. Some of his great efforts included his return to Jerusalem to obtain the brass plates and the building of a ship when it was considered impossible. In first Nephi we read:

 

“And it came to pass that I, Nephi, said unto my father: I will go and do the things which the Lord hath commanded, for I know that the Lord giveth no commandments unto the children of men, save he shall prepare a way for them that they may accomplish the thing which he commandeth them.” 3

 

My father was a brick layer, and at the age of 11 or 12, I was a “hod carrier.” For those that do not know what a hod carrier is, he is the one that does all the menial tasks for a brick layer. One of the great things that my father taught me was how to work. If I wanted clothes, I worked for them. I bought my own car, and I put myself through college, because if I didn’t do that, I would not have a college education. My father helped me to achieve my goals by showing me how to work when I was very young. If you have learned the value of hard work, you have certainly learned one of the most powerful of life’s lessons of success.

 

Several years ago, I learned the results of a survey about the joy of work. The results were this:

 

 

Where would your answer fall in this survey? Do you love to work?

 

Mary Anne and I have six children. One of our daughters, Debbie, who is here this evening, was an All American High School Track Runner. I helped coach her. I taught her that first you run with your heart, then you run with your head and last of all you run with your feet. I am sure that many could run faster than Debbie, but they didn’t win.

 

Life and work are a lot like running. First of all it starts in your heart. You must have a desire to work hard.  What is recorded in your heart no one can change. Second, you must work with your mind. When we work with our minds it is never boring. I have often said that if my job was to empty the garbage I would do it in one half of the time that it took the guy before me. You can become creative, and find new ways to make your job better. Finally you must work with your feet. These days those who work the hardest are the ones who will get a job and keep it. Life is very competitive and those with strong work ethics become the winners, or the ones who get the jobs.

 

Doctrine and Covenants, Section 4, teaches these same principles.

 

“Therefore, O ye that embark in the service of God, see that ye serve him with all your heart, might, mind and strength, that ye may stand blameless before God at the last day.” 4

 

It is obvious when one doesn’t like his job because he will waste time, not be productive, and be the first to leave. A great worker is diligent. As we strive to be like Nephi, we will come to know that diligence is more important than intelligence. 

 

You are going into a world where many are unemployed. You may have heard or will hear, “There are no jobs.” I would propose that there are always some people working. The question is, will you be the one that has a job? If you have a strong desire to work and are qualified, you can find a job.

 

I will suggest one way to get a job. You need to find a place where people are working and you meet the qualifications. Upon finding people working, ask to talk to the boss. The conversation may go something like this:

 

 

The unconventional idea of working for free can help you achieve your goal of getting a job.  It is better to work for free than not to be working. Many people I know have tried this technique. If you are the best, arriving early and leaving late, after a short period of time you may have a job. In one case they released three workers and my friend received a full time job doing the work of three people. What is your reputation as a doer and worker? How strong is your desire and love for work?

 

The Second Seed is that of Setting Challenging Goals

 

In Proverbs we read:

 

“Where there is no vision, the people perish: but he that keepeth the law, happy is he.” 5

 

Once an individual has a vision, that vision is achieved by setting and achieving challenging goals. To quote Elder M. Russell Ballard,

 

“I am so thoroughly convinced that if we don’t set goals in our life and learn how to master the techniques of living to reach our goals, we can reach a ripe old age and look back on our life only to see that we reached but a small part of our full potential.  When one learns to master the principles of setting a goal, he will then be able to make a great difference in the results he attains in this life.” 6

 

As stated by Elder Ballard, goals alone are insufficient. We must live and plan to reach our goals. 

 

One time, where I was working I had a goal to save 10 times my annual salary. I knew that if I saved the company that much money I would always have work. As part of achieving that goal I had an idea that would save the company I was working for $150,000. I knew that it was a great idea, but it was a completely new idea, and I knew that it might not be accepted easily. I presented the idea it was turned down. I worked on it, presented it again, and it was turned down again. The more I worked on it, and the more I researched it, I was sure about it, so I presented it five times. It was finally accepted. My boss was thrilled with the results, because it made him look good. That happened many years ago. The approval of that idea has resulted in savings of millions of dollars for that company. The achievement of challenging goals will not come easily. It will require dedication and persistence.

 

What is your vision? How much can you accomplish? The answer to this question is much more than you ever dreamed. You need to learn to think outside the box. Don’t let others tell you it cannot be done. If you work hard at your job, and enjoy it, and set challenging goals, then through hard work achieve them, you will be the one who keeps his job. As President Boyd K. Packer has stated, “You get what you go for!”

 

The Third Seed is that of Service

 

In the book of John is recorded a conversation between the Savior and Peter:

 

 “So when they had dined, Jesus saith to Simon Peter, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me more than these? He saith unto him, Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love thee. He saith unto him, Feed my lambs.

He saith to him again the second time, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me? He saith unto him, Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love thee. He saith unto him, Feed my sheep.

He saith unto him the third time, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me? Peter was grieved because he said unto him the third time, Lovest thou me? And he said unto him, Lord, thou knowest all things; thou knowest that I love thee. Jesus saith unto him, Feed my sheep.” 7

 

Service to others makes us better. As Peter was instructed, the world has a great need for people that know how to help others become better.

 

President Monson is the perfect example of reaching out to the one and serving others. President Packer said this about President Monson:

 

“He is more Christlike than the rest of us.  He’s known for emphasizing and elevating things that are most important, the ordinary things.  He is the one for whom the widow and the orphan are not just statements in a book.” 8

 

When I was a mission president, I taught the great value of service. Sometimes missionaries would come to me and be unhappy, or want to go home. I often found that what they needed most was to get into their work as a missionary. As they learned to love the people they were teaching, they learned to serve them.  As we learn to serve others, we forget ourselves, and enjoy life a lot more. It is when we think only about ourselves that we become unhappy. Get to work! Serve those around you! It will bring you much joy and much peace!

 

I have a favorite poem that illustrates the value of our influence and service.

 

The Touch of the Master's Hand


'Twas battered and scarred,

And the auctioneer thought it

scarcely worthwhile

To waste much time on the old violin,

but he held it up with a smile.

 

"What am I bid, good folks", he cried,

"Who’ll start the bidding for me?"

"One dollar, one dollar, then two, only two?"

"Two dollars, who’ll make it three?"

"Three dollars once, three dollars twice, going and gone said he."

 

But, No,

From the room far back a gray haired man

Came forward and picked up the bow,

Then wiping the dust from the old violin,

And tightening up the strings,

He played a melody, pure and sweet

As sweet as the angel sings.

 

The music ceased and the auctioneer,

With a voice that was quiet and low,

Said "What am I bid for the old violin?"

As he held it up with the bow.

 

"A thousand, and who’ll make it two?"

"Two thousand, and who’ll make it three?"

"Three thousand once, three thousand twice,

Going and gone!" said he.

 

The people cheered,

But some of them cried,

"We do not quite understand."

"What changed its' worth?”

The man replied,

"The Touch of the Master’s Hand."

 

And many a man with life out of tune,

All battered and torn with sin,

Is auctioned cheap to the thoughtless crowd,

Much like that old violin.

 

A mess of pottage, a glass of wine,

A game and he travels on.

He is going once, he is going twice,

He is going and almost gone.

 

But the Master comes,

And the foolish crowd never can quite understand,

The worth of a soul and the change that is wrought

By the Touch of the Masters' Hand. 9  

 

May we have the touch of the master’s hand and help others become better through our service.

 

The Fourth Seed is that of Being Hungry to Learn

 

We read in Doctrine and Covenants:

 

Wherefore, now let every man learn his duty, and to act in the office in which he is appointed, in all diligence. 10

 

Sam Walton, the founder of WalMart, was always interested in learning from others. I knew Sam Walton and was impressed that he felt that everyone could teach him something even though he was one of the richest men in the United States. Maybe that is why he came to be one of the wealthiest. He lived simply and ran his business on a shoestring, but always knew there was a better way.

 

Another example of this is President Gordon B. Hinckley. During his many years in the presidency of the Church he focused on achieving spiritual heights and improving many of the programs of the Church. He loved new ideas and took many of them to the Lord. The Church grew much stronger as he focused on better ways to strengthen the Church.

 

Some of these wonderful changes included the Perpetual Education Fund, small temples and the Conference Center. President Thomas S. Monson continues that prophetic direction today. A great example of finding better ways of doing something is the example of the Pioneers traveling from Nauvoo to the Salt Lake Valley. 

 

When the Pioneers traveled from Nauvoo to Salt Lake City it took several months to get there. With the stagecoach it took weeks to travel the same distance. With the invention of the railroad the time was reduced to days, and now we can travel by airplane in 2 to 3 hours.

 

Those who are hungry to learn know that there is always a better way. We as members of the Church of Jesus Christ have a great advantage, the gift of the Holy Ghost. He knows all and cares about the spiritual, the temporal, the family, and all aspects of our lives. He helps us learn how to do things better.  He whispers to us and he helps us many times every single day if we will listen to him. I have a little book of inspiration. It doesn’t look like much, but is very useful to me. I have learned that the Holy Ghost talks to me. If I write my thoughts down and do them, He keeps talking to me. If we don’t listen to Him, He will quit talking to us. We must be hungry to learn, and our very best teacher is the Holy Ghost. Studying the scriptures is a great way to receive revelation. That is one reason why we have them and study them daily. They will teach us where to go and what to do, in all aspects of our daily lives. 

 

The Fifth Seed is that of Solving Problems

 

The Doctrine and Covenants teaches how to solve problems.

 

 

But, behold, I say unto you, that you must study it out in your mind; then you must ask me if it be right, and if it is right I will cause that your bosom shall burn within you; therefore, you shall feel that it is right.  11

 

 

When I was a young bishop in Saint Louis Missouri, we had six children and I was the head of a company. There were many successful people in our ward, including the stake president, many stake leaders and successful business people. I remember thinking, “If my life was just like so and so, life would be perfect.”

 

Mary Anne will always remember the night I came home and said, “Now that I know many of the problems of the ward, I don’t want to change places with anyone.” I came to realize that everyone has challenges. It is how we approach the challenges and go about solving them that makes the difference and helps us learn to become better. The solutions are not easy and do not always result in the problem disappearing, but we can do something and usually things will improve.

 

We must study the problem out in our minds, pray about it, and listen for the personal revelation Heavenly Father is ready to give us. As we work out our problems, in faith and in prayer we will find the solution.

 

My motto has become “love problems, love life!” The world needs problem solvers. “I can’t do that, this is just the way I am,” is another common statement. We can solve problems. As we become more like the Savior and our Father in Heaven we will become better problem solvers.

 

The seeds of:

 

 

If planted, will help us in all aspects of our life. It will provide a bountiful harvest.

 

May the blessings of heaven be with you and your families as you leave this great institution. I once again congratulate you. I want to testify to you, that as you listen to the Holy Ghost, as you have been instructed today by President Clark, he will guide you. I testify that Thomas S. Monson is God’s prophet on the earth today. I have watched, I have listened, I have felt, I know.

 

I know that Joseph Smith saw God the Father and the Son in the sacred grove many years ago. One day it was October; October in the east is beautiful. I was there alone, I knelt, I prayed, I know that Joseph saw the Father and the Son.

 

I know that the Book of Mormon is true, and as you will sup from its pages, it will guide you and direct you. But most of all I know that the Savior lives, that Jesus is the Christ. That his atonement works in our lives, and only though him can we return to the presence of the Father.

 

May God bless you on this very important day in your life is my humble prayer in the name of Jesus Christ, amen.

 

 

 

1 Galatians 6:7

2 William George Jordan, The Kingship of Self-Control, 1898, 1

3 1 Nephi 3:7

4 D&C 4:2

5 Proverbs 29:18

6 Preach My Gospel, 2004, 146

7 John 21:15-17

8 Heidi S. Swinton, To The Rescue, the Biography of Thomas S. Monson, 2010, 1

9 Myra Brooks Welch

10 D&C 107:99

11 D&C 9:8



http://www.byui.edu/Presentations/Transcripts/Graduation/2012_07_20_Clark.htm

 

 

 

 

Before I offer a few remarks to the graduates, I would like to say a word to the parents. Thank you for entrusting your children to us. We love them very much. As I look at you today, I think of all the prayers you have said on behalf of your children. I think of all the home evenings and family dinners.  I think of all the times you sat up waiting for them to come home. I think of your devotion to them and your love for them.

 

I would like to tell you something about your children. One of the most wonderful things about your children is the light in their eyes and the love of the Savior in their hearts. These are priceless spiritual gifts. Your children have worked hard at BYU-Idaho. They have qualified for the blessings of increased faith, testimony, knowledge, and skills that will be of great value to them and their families and to the kingdom of God. They have become disciples of Jesus Christ. The Lord will send them on His errands in a world in turmoil, and the Holy Ghost will go with them.

 

Now, I speak to the graduates. My dear brothers and sisters, I love you very much. I want to share with you today words of counsel from the Prophet Joseph Smith. I hope you will always remember these words of the Prophet as you face the many wonderful opportunities and the many challenges that will come to you in the years ahead. I quote from a message given to Brigham Young by the Prophet Joseph three years after the Prophet was martyred:

 

“Tell the people to be humble and faithful and sure to keep the Spirit of the Lord and it will lead them right.  Be careful and not turn away the small still voice; it will teach [you what] to do and where to go; it will yield the fruits of the kingdom. Tell the brethren to keep their hearts open to conviction so that when the Holy Ghost comes to them, their hearts will be ready to receive it. They can tell the Spirit of the Lord from all other spirits. It will whisper peace and joy to their souls, and it will take malice, hatred, envying, strife, and all evil from their hearts; and their whole desire will be to do good, bring forth righteousness, and build up the kingdom of God. Tell the brethren if they will follow the Spirit of the Lord they will go right.” (Teachings of the Presidents of the Church: Joseph Smith, (2007), 98)

 

I say to you tonight, go forward unafraid with confidence and trust in the Lord. Always keep your covenants so that you will have the Holy Ghost with you. Never do anything, say anything, wear anything, watch anything, or go anywhere that would offend the Spirit and deprive you of the guidance and power of the Holy Ghost. If you follow the Prophet’s counsel, you and your family will enjoy the blessings of heaven. When you come face-to-face with the opportunities and challenges of life, the Savior will be with you. He will bless you with spiritual strength and guidance through the power of the Holy Ghost. The Savior has been preparing you for a long time for just this time and season.  Here is His promise to you:

 

“... I will go before your face. I will be on your right hand and on your left, and my Spirit shall be in your hearts, and mine angels round about you, to bear you up.” (D&C 84:88)

 

 

I bear witness to you, my dear brothers and sisters, that this scripture is true. God our Father lives and loves us. His Beloved Son, the Lord Jesus Christ, is the Savior and Redeemer. I have seen His light. I know His power. I have felt His love. I know He lives. His church and kingdom have been restored through the Prophet Joseph Smith never to be taken from the earth again. 

 

We send you out into the world tonight with our love, our confidence, and our trust. You have a great work to do in the kingdom. I know that if you will live to be worthy of the Holy Ghost, the light and power and redeeming love of Jesus Christ will be in your eyes and in your hearts and in your lives forever.

 

I so testify, in the sacred name of Jesus Christ, amen.



http://www.byui.edu/Presentations/Transcripts/EducationWeek/2012_07_27_Clayton.htm

 

 

 

 

I am grateful to join with you for BYU–Idaho 2012 Education Week. I pray that the blessings of heaven may rest upon us as we meet together for a few minutes this afternoon.

 

You may have seen the remarkable poster that has been used to publicize Education Week. I found it particularly beautiful and meaningful. In the background the magnificent Rexburg Idaho Temple beckons, with dark clouds in the distance signaling a summer rainstorm may lie ahead. The foreground shows children and teenagers or young adults, perhaps parents, walking toward the temple through a wheat field that has recently been harvested. Some walk hand in hand. A few walk alone. Each carries a small bundle or sheaf of wheat. They don’t appear to hurry, but neither do they appear to wander. They all walk a direct path toward the temple.

 

Pure children walking toward the temple, who gather like sheaves the good around them, are the heart of my message. Those children live in our homes. It is our divine privilege and responsibility to help them recognize the eternal truth that surrounds them, be worthy to enter the temple, and chart a lifelong course that will “keep them in the right way.”1

 

I am struck, as you likely have been as well, by one of the implicit messages in the Book of Mormon. Among many other things, the Book of Mormon is a chronicle of families. From Lehi and Sariah to Mormon and Moroni, we read about marriages, parents, children, siblings, grandchildren, and daughters and sons-in-law. Some of the accounts tell of people who were exceedingly good, the Nephis, Helamans, and Moronis of the book.

 

Other characters from the Book of Mormon remind us that even in the best homes, things sometimes can go quite badly. For example, Lehi and Sariah were caused much heartache by some of their children. King Mosiah and his wife, and Alma Sr. and his wife, raised sons who must have caused them great concern and sorrow as their sons went about seeking to destroy the Church. The sons of Mosiah and Alma the younger eventually came to themselves and returned to the path, but they had given their parents great grief.

 

Not surprisingly, then, we find Lehi’s dream recorded in the first pages of the Book of Mormon. It has much to do with families. You remember the account: Lehi beheld in a dream or vision “a tree, whose fruit was desirable to make one happy.” He went forth and partook of the fruit, and learned that it was “most sweet, above all that [he] ever before tasted.”2 [It] filled [his] soul with exceedingly great joy; wherefore [he] began to be desirous that [his] family should partake of it also; for [he] knew that it was desirable above all other fruit.”3

 

After tasting the fruit and learning that it was delicious to his soul, he looked and saw Sariah, Sam, and Nephi, and “they stood as if they knew not whither they should go.”4 He “beckoned unto them; and called them with a loud voice that they should come unto [him], and partake of the fruit, which was desirable above all other fruit.”5 They hearkened to him.6 Lehi then was desirous that Laman and Lemuel should come and partake of the fruit. . . but they would not come.”7 That varying receptiveness of our children to the gospel message is a repeated theme in the Book of Mormon, and often a worry for parents. 

 

Lehi’s dream explained some of the reasons people are more or less receptive to the gospel message. You recall that Lehi saw a strait and narrow path and a rod of iron that led to the tree and the fruit.8 “Numberless concourses of people were pressing forward [toward] the path which led to the tree.”9 As they sought for the path, a “mist of darkness [arose], yea, even an exceedingly great mist of darkness, insomuch that they who had commenced in the path did lose their way, that they wandered off and were lost.”10 Nephi explained that the mists of darkness were a symbol of the temptations of the devil.11

 

Others seen by Lehi found the strait and narrow path and made their way to the tree and partook of the fruit, but he thereafter noted that they “did cast about their eyes as if they were ashamed.” Lehi then saw a great and spacious building standing in the air, high above the ground. It was “filled with people, . . . old and young, . . . male and female; . . . their manner of dress was exceedingly fine; and they were . . . mocking and pointing their fingers towards those who had [partaken] of the fruit. [Those who tasted of the fruit and afterwards became ashamed because of the scoffing] “fell away into forbidden paths and were lost.” 12

 

Lehi saw other explanations for how people end up far from the path of righteousness. However, the mists of darkness or temptation and feeling ashamed because of the ridicule to which gospel beliefs and practices are sometimes subjected, are two major challenges parents continue to confront today as they seek to raise their children in righteousness and help them taste the fruit for themselves.

 

We are all familiar with the problems that Lehi and Sariah had with Laman, Lemuel, and the sons of Ishmael and his wife. Those problems and their sorry legacy across succeeding generations set the backdrop for much of the secular history recounted in the Book of Mormon. Insofar as we know, neither Laman nor Lemuel ever repented and returned to the path, notwithstanding the remarkable, even miraculous spiritual experiences that were theirs. Although Laman and Lemuel were raised in the same family as Sam, Nephi, Jacob, and Joseph, they struggled with the strait and narrow path and never reached the tree or tasted its fruit.

 

A less prominent but spiritually important history involves King Benjamin and his descendants. Following King Benjamin’s timeless discourse, his subjects fell to the earth,

 

“. . . for the fear of the Lord had come upon them. They had viewed themselves in their own carnal state, even less than the dust of the earth.  And they all cried aloud with one voice, saying: O have mercy, and apply the atoning blood of Christ that we may receive forgiveness of our sins, and our hearts may be purified; for we believe in Jesus Christ, the Son of God, who created heaven and earth, and all things; who shall come down among the children of men.”13

 

When this occurred, the people “were filled with joy, having received a remission of their sins, and having peace of conscience, because of their exceeding faith in Jesus Christ.”14 King Benjamin then promised them that if they would repent of their sins and forsake them, then they would “always rejoice, and be filled with the love of God, and always retain a remission of [their] sins.”15

 

The people told King Benjamin that they had experienced a “mighty change” of heart.16 They said that they were “willing to enter into a covenant with . . . God to do his will, and to be obedient to his commandments in all things that he shall command us, all the remainder of our days . . .”17 

 

Now, when they had entered into this covenant,

 

“. . . King Benjamin thought . . . that he should take the names of all those who had entered into a covenant with God to keep his commandments.

 

And it came to pass that there was not one soul, except it were little children, but who had entered into the covenant and had taken upon them the name of Christ.”18

 

Now we have a picture in our minds of this remarkable spiritual change of heart and among the people of King Benjamin, and of their entering a covenant to obey God to the end of their lives. So far, the picture looks great, doesn’t it?  But stay tuned.

 

If we move forward in time just one generation, the picture becomes terribly blemished. You will recall that the only ones who heard King Benjamin speak but did not enter into the covenant were the little children. They were too young to understand his words and to make that covenant. Some of the most chilling words in the Book of Mormon concern those little children once they were grown. We read,

 

“Now it came to pass that there were many of the rising generation that could not understand the words of King Benjamin, being little children at the time he spake unto his people; and they did not believe the tradition of their fathers.

 

They did not believe what had been said concerning the resurrection of the dead, neither did they believe concerning the coming of Christ.

 

And now because of their unbelief they could not understand the word of God; and their hearts were hardened.

 

And they would not be baptized; neither would they join the church.  And they were a separate people as to their faith, and remained so ever after, even in their carnal and sinful state; for they would not call upon the Lord their God.

 

And now in the reign of Mosiah they were not half so numerous as the people of God; but because of the dissensions among the brethren they became more numerous.

 

For it came to pass that they did deceive many with their flattering words, who were in the church, and did cause them to commit many sins . . .”19

 

These passages always raise questions in my mind: Why? What happened to these children? What went wrong? How did these children miss learning gospel truths? Didn’t they hold family home evening? Was there something their parents did or didn’t do? Didn’t they go to Primary, Young Men, and Young Women classes? The record of the Book of Mormon does not address these questions.

 

We see a similar pattern after the sign was given in the land of promise concerning the birth of the Savior. You recall that the sign of his birth was that there would be a day a night and another day in which there would be no darkness. The people were told that they would see the sun set but that the sky would not darken. That very thing happened, just as prophesied. The Book of Mormon records that,

 

“. . . at the going down of the sun there was no darkness; and the people began to be astonished because there was no darkness when the night came.

 

And there were many, who had not believed the words of the prophets, who fell to the earth and became as if they were dead, for they knew that the great plan of destruction which they had laid for those who believed in the words of the prophets had been frustrated; . . .

 

And they began to know that the Son of God must shortly appear; yea, in fine, all the people upon the face of the whole earth from the west to the east, both in the land north and in the land south, were so exceedingly astonished that they fell to the earth.

 

For they knew that the prophets had testified of these things for many years . . . and they began to fear because of their iniquity and their unbelief.

 

And it came to pass that there was no darkness in all that night, but it was as light as though it was mid-day.  And it came to pass that the sun did rise in the morning again . . . and they knew that it was the day that the Lord should be born, because of the sign which had been given.”20

 

Notwithstanding this phenomenal experience, the scriptural record states that “from [that] time forth there began to be lyings sent forth among the people, by Satan, to harden their hearts, to the intent that they might not believe in those signs and wonders which they had seen.”21 Many of the people were baptized and turned to the Lord, but as the years went by “ . . . many dissenters of the Nephites fled to the Gadianton robbers, causing much sorrow unto those Nephites who did remain in the land.”22

 

The Lamanites confronted a similar situation:

 

“And there was also a cause of much sorrow among the Lamanites; for behold, they had many children who did grow up and began to wax strong in years, that they became for themselves, and were led away by some who were Zoramites, by their lyings and their flattering words, to join those Gadianton robbers.

 

And thus were the Lamanites afflicted also, and began to decrease as to their faith and righteousness, because of the wickedness of the rising generation.”23

 

Again, we ask: Why? Why did some of the Nephites become dissenters after having personally seen such miraculous evidence of gospel truth? What happened to the children of the Lamanites so that as they matured, they failed to find the strait and narrow path to the fruit? Was there a failure that we can detect and thereby avoid? Are there patterns in these histories that bear examination and comparison to our own days?

 

When we read about mists of darkness, we understand that we are reading about temptations. Not much has changed about the nature of temptation since the dawn of time. It is still an appeal to our appetites, our vanity, or our desire for power. The so-called modern world presents all of the same old temptations that countless generations before us have confronted, although today those temptations come with electronic enhancements - its mists of darkness magnified by megawatts. But there is nothing new about the dead ends that temptation’s allures lead to. Breaking the commandments still inevitably yields the same old heartache, regret, and remorse it always has. That hasn’t changed and never will. Protecting ourselves and our children against the mists of darkness has become more urgent as the adversary’s sales techniques for his same-old-sins-as-always become pervasive in our culture and more sophisticated.

 

We also see the Church, its doctrines, and practices subjected to public scrutiny and occasional ridicule and contortion. The new electronic world, which shortens distances between countries to milliseconds as messages speed across the internet, is so different from earlier years. A message can go viral in a matter of hours, regardless of whether it is true and fair. Some reporting can be accurate but some of it also can also be misguided, negligent, or motivated by antipathy for the Church and its message.

 

Other attacks can come from time to time from those who are or were members of the Church. Some of these who label themselves “insiders” mischaracterize the Church’s beliefs and history. Others cloak themselves in the robes of believers but in fact have long since taken up residence in the great and spacious building. They portray themselves as too wise to embrace this doctrine or that one. They proclaim that they are better educated and informed than others and thus can be trusted to reliably identify purported defects in Church leaders, history, or practices and thereby protect less well-informed and more gullible believers. Their teachings often ridicule the Church, its teachings, and the believers. This group strains at doctrinal and historical gnats but unconsciously swallows camels as they pick at some point but miss the grandeur, scope, and power of the work of salvation the Lord set in motion in 1820.

 

Another challenge, perhaps more subtle than the ones we have been talking about, is the influence of affluence and abundance. This trial hardly seems to be a trial at all. Can there be too much of a good thing? Yes, there can be, when ease and prosperity begin to guide decisions and moderate obedience to fundamental gospel principles. This affliction has been described as getting “caught up in the thick of thin things,” or being “anxiously engaged” in a cause that doesn’t matter. This occurs when the things of the world, its enticements and allures, increasingly distract us from things of lasting value. Our attention slowly moves toward interests of only passing fancy, and the way we use our time soon follows. Things of little meaning begin to encroach against time that should be devoted to better things, and gradually we wander from the path to the fruit without even being aware that we are doing so. Some of these pursuits and interests may be harmless, but they are of no real value either. Unfortunately, some who wander may justify thoughts and other indulgences that they would never attempt to defend before the Lord Himself. 

 

The Book of Mormon captures the spirit of this challenge with these words:

 

And others will he pacify, and lull them away into carnal security, that they will say: All is well in Zion; yea, Zion prospereth, all is well—and thus the devil cheateth their souls, and leadeth them away carefully down to hell.

 

And behold, others he flattereth away, and telleth them there is no hell; and he saith unto them: I am no devil, for there is none—and thus he whispereth in their ears, until he grasps them with his awful chains, from whence there is no deliverance.24

 

Together the challenges of temptation, ridicule, and ease, constitute just some of the uneven terrain today’s pioneering parents and their children must cross. The pioneers of the 1800s knew that they were crossing the plains. Their very survival was sometimes a question. Today’s Rocky Ridges and Sweetwater Rivers don’t come complete with handcarts. We may not even recognize the trial of our faith when we are in the midst of it. If we don’t, it is even more unlikely that our children will. Indeed, our challenges seem to be more like those that we have reviewed today from the Book of Mormon, where people surrounded by truth wandered away from it, walking in darkness when the light of the gospel shone like the sun at noon day around them. We are not the first to confront such difficulties, and we certainly won’t be the last. Our families must be the bulwark of defense against this deadly spiritual hazard.

 

Section 93 of the Doctrine and Covenants explains that:

 

“Every spirit of man was innocent in the beginning; and God having redeemed man from the fall, men became again, in their infant state, innocent before God.

 

And that wicked one cometh and taketh away light and truth, through disobedience, from the children of men, and because of the tradition of their fathers.

 

But I have commanded you to bring up your children in light and truth.”25

 

Thus, we lose light and truth as individuals as a consequence of our own personal disobedience of the commandments and also as a consequence of the traditions of our fathers, meaning our families. One meaning for traditions is the family culture in which we were raised or in which we raise our children. We lose light and truth when our family culture crowds them out of the home.

 

No home is perfect, but some homes do a better job of passing down correct traditions, or correct gospel habits and patterns of belief, to their children. Similarly, no children are perfect. Some come more inclined toward obedience than others. In this regard, it is important to remember something taught by President James E. Faust. He said,

 

“Who are good parents? They are those who have lovingly, prayerfully, and earnestly tried to teach their children by example and precept “to pray, and to walk uprightly before the Lord.” This is true even though some of their children are disobedient or worldly. Children come into this world with their own distinct spirits and personality traits. Some children “would challenge any set of parents under any set of circumstances. … Perhaps there are others who would bless the lives of, and be a joy to, almost any father or mother.” Successful parents are those who have sacrificed and struggled to do the best they can in their own family circumstances.”26

 

My wife and I live in Salt Lake City, up along the hills on the east side of town. An indigenous tree that grows in our part of town is commonly referred to as scrub oak. These trees tend to be shorter and have much thinner trunks than do other oak trees. They grow as volunteers and have been adopted by many homeowners as part of their landscaping. We have several trees in the front yard of our home and a few more in the rear. The scrub oaks are quite old. They have endured countless winters, hot dry summers, the construction of nearby houses, and the benign neglect of well-intentioned but hapless gardeners like me. Somehow, notwithstanding all the reasons that they should fare poorly, they do beautifully.

 

We have a large pot that sits along the walkway to our front door. We try to keep flowers blooming in the pot from early spring until late fall.  The pot sits directly under limbs of one of our scrub oaks. A couple of years ago I was tending to the flowers in the pot when I discovered that some of the acorns from the scrub oak had fallen into the pot. I pulled on a tiny seedling scrub oak, just visible a couple of inches above the surface of the potting soil. To my surprise, I continued to pull and pull and the root for the seedling kept coming. I found another couple of seedlings and pulled them out as well. Each one had a root structure that was much longer or deeper than the above the ground portion of the little tree would ever reveal. I was so astonished by the length of the roots that I took a photo of some of the roots next to a 12-inch ruler, to be sure that the lesson I was learning was not lost.

 

The scrub oak trees are prepared by nature to be successful in the somewhat harsh environment in which they live. They are naturally designed to endure long cold winters, windy nights, hot summers, and variable rainfall. One obvious key to their success is that deep root, which protects them against the various threats to their well-being and very lives.

 

That secret of the scrub oak seedling’s success – its long roots – suggests that we can do much to protect ourselves and the rising generation by ensuring that our spiritual roots have been sent down deep into the soils of faith in the Lord Jesus Christ and His Restored Gospel. By doing so we become rooted with a lifelong and enduring faith.

 

I will suggest six steps that we can take to help us and our children to send down roots deep into the soils of faith.

 

1. Strengthen Your Testimony

 

We can begin by ensuring that we have a personal, burning, deeply-seated, lifelong testimony of the restored gospel. This testimony is available to all who will pay the price to receive it. The Book of Mormon is central to receiving a testimony that can withstand any temptation and weather any challenge. The introduction to the Book of Mormon states:

 

“We invite all men everywhere to read the Book of Mormon, to ponder in their hearts the message it contains, and then to ask God, the Eternal Father, in the name of Christ if the book is true. Those who pursue this course and ask in faith will gain a testimony of its truth and divinity by the power of the Holy Ghost.  (See Moroni 10:3–5.)

 

Those who gain this divine witness from the Holy Spirit will also come to know by the same power that Jesus Christ is the Savior of the world, that Joseph Smith is his revelator and prophet in these last days, and that The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is the Lord's kingdom once again established on the earth, preparatory to the second coming of the Messiah.”27

 

This path to testimony applies to all, including and perhaps especially those who have been raised surrounded by the restored gospel but who have never personally made a real, searching, genuine effort to find out if the message of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is true. The promise is that those who “read the Book of Mormon,” “ponder in their hearts” its message, ask God in faith in the name of Christ if the book is true, “will gain a testimony of its truth and divinity by the power of the Holy Ghost.”28 By pursuing this course, they will also come to know of the divinity of the Savior, the divine mission of Joseph Smith, and the heavenly origin of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

 

To ask in faith is to act with real intent, affirming sincerely to God that one is not asking out of curiosity but with firm commitment to conform one’s life to the answer that comes from heaven. This means “acting no hypocrisy and no deception before God” in our reading, pondering, and praying.29 Academic interest in the book is not sufficient. A spiritual joyride, like taking a car for a test drive, is not enough. What is required is the genuine desire to obey God if revelation comes that the book is true. This necessarily means reading in such a way as to seek confirming spiritual evidence that the book is true. It means choosing study materials that are intended to strengthen rather than weaken faith. It means accepting the Book of Mormon’s promise as a promise from God and taking Him at His word. Whenever one applies the Book of Mormon’s promise faithfully, with real intent, the answer will come. It may come immediately and powerfully, or it may come gradually, almost without notice, but the promise will always be fulfilled. Always means always.

 

2. Keep the Commandments

 

Consistent with the principles for reading, pondering about and praying to learn that the Book of Mormon is true, is the requirement that one keep the commandments of God. The Savior taught this principle concerning gaining a testimony:

 

 

“My doctrine is not mine, but his that sent me.

If any man will do his will, he shall know of the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of myself.” 30

 

 

Obedience to the principles of the Gospel is a fundamental element in gaining, maintaining, and strengthening a testimony. If we do God’s will, we shall then learn whether the doctrine comes from God or man. This is not a call for fanatical, blind obedience, but an invitation to heartfelt, sincere obedience that is given because of what one sees, feels, and learns when he or she keeps the commandments.  

 

3. Serve in the Church

 

The Lord revealed to Joseph Smith that those who would serve in the Church would be blessed with a testimony of his divine appointment as a prophet.

 

“For, behold, I will bless all those who labor in my vineyard with a mighty blessing, and they shall believe on his [Joseph Smith’s] words, which are given him through me by the Comforter,”31

 

A call to serve is an opportunity to deepen spiritual roots and strengthen faith.

 

4. Keep Priorities in Order

 

This principle for deepening our roots is based on ordered priorities. It is connected to the principle of integrity, of living consistently the covenants one has made with God and with spouse. President Gordon B. Hinckley taught priesthood leaders across the world:

 

“Each of us has a fourfold responsibility. First, we have a responsibility to our families. Second, we have a responsibility to our employers. Third, we have a responsibility to the Lord’s work. Fourth, we have a responsibility to ourselves.”32

 

At times each of these priorities will take precedence on a given day and hour, but overall they should fit within this order. As couples and families we determine how much time we will spend in each of these endeavors and then stick with it, putting things in order and keeping them there. Abiding by correct priorities will help deepen our roots.

 

5. Strengthen Our Marriages

 

Integrity teaches that one must live up to one’s promises in all circumstances. When other interests edge their way ahead of home and hearth, a spouse may rightly feel disappointed and misled and children may correctly perceive that keeping covenants must not be important to us. These feelings and perceptions can slowly wither a marriage and drain a child’s budding faith and testimony. 

 

We are taught:

 

“The Lord has commanded husbands and wives to cleave to each other (see Genesis 2:24; D&C 42:22). In this commandment, the word cleave means to be completely devoted and faithful to someone. Married couples cleave to God and one another by serving and loving each other and by keeping covenants in complete delity to one another and to God (see D&C 25:13).

 

A couple is to become one in establishing their family as the basis of a righteous life. Latter-day Saint husbands and wives leave behind their single life and establish their marriage as the rst priority in their lives. They allow no other person or interest to have greater priority in their lives than keeping the covenants they have made with God and each other.”33

 

Strengthening our marriages deepens gospel roots.

 

6. Strengthen Children

 

I believe that there is much we can do in our homes to help build faith in the rising generation. Surely some of those who have wandered at any point in human history might have been more faithful had their homes been better. In homes where the gospel flourishes, children more easily prosper. They don’t wonder why there are differences between what they hear from the pulpit and what they observe at home. Habits of faith are established, like scripture reading, family home evening, and family prayer. Children learn from the example of their parents what it means to love, honor, and cherish each other. They are more likely to read the Book of Mormon, pray of their own volition, and receive their own testimonies. They see what a great home looks like, know what it feels like, and have a pattern for starting their own. They observe love and conversion in action, and their souls are warmed by what they see and feel. Thus safe at home, children are better able to send down tap roots deep into spiritual soil, and build testimonies that burn brightly forever and conversion that cannot be extinguished.

 

In homes like this, the rising generation is safe. Children raised there will, as Paul wrote, be “firmly rooted and built up in [the Savior], and stablished in the faith.”34 They won’t be spoiled “through philosophy and vain deceit, after the tradition of men, after the rudiments of the world,” because they will be able to see and feel their way through the sophistry.35 Their rootedness becomes their iron rod in the mists of darkness.36 If there are ravening wolves circling and threatening at the heels of the flock, they will recognize them and detect their false claims. They will see through the mists of darkness, endure the heat of the day during persecution, and survive frigid nights of ridicule. 

 

There will always be the sons of Mosiah and Almas, who may wander from the flock, but the Lord will feel after them and bring them back into the fold. The righteousness of their parents will help to secure that end for them. The day of their return may not be soon, but in the Lord’s own way and time, upon conditions of repentance, deliverance will surely come. There will also be some Lamans and Lemuels among our families. We simply trust that the Lord will deal with them and with us in His own loving, merciful way.

 

The theme for this year’s BYU–Idaho Education Week is, “Lord, I Would Follow Thee.”37 My prayer is that we may follow Him most closely and more carefully at home. This is a prayer for our children and for the rising generation, that in time each one of them may also pray, “Lord, I would follow thee.”

 

In the name of Jesus Christ, Amen.

 

1 Mosiah 27:10

2 1 Nephi 8:11

3 1 Nephi 8:12

4 1 Nephi 8:14

5 1 Nephi 8:15

8 1 Nephi 8:19-20

12 1 Nephi 8:25-28

13 Mosiah 4:1-2

14 Mosiah 4:3

15 Mosiah 4:12

16 Mosiah 5:2

17 Mosiah 5:5

18 Mosiah 6:1-2

19 Mosiah 26:1-5

20 3 Nephi 1:15-19

21 3 Nephi 1:22

22 3 Nephi 1:28

23 3 Nephi 1:29-30

24 2 Nephi 28:21-22

25 D&C 93:38-40

26 “Dear Are The Sheep That Have Wandered,” Ensign, April 2003

27 The Book of Mormon, Introduction, last two paragraphs

28 The Book of Mormon, Introduction, second to the last paragraph

29 2 Nephi 31:13

30 John 7:16-17

31 D&C 21:9

32 Worldwide Leadership Training Meeting, June 21, 2003, p. 22

33 Handbook 2, Section 1.3.1

34 Colossians 2:7

35 Colossians 2:8

36 1 Nephi 8:19-20, 24

37 Hymns, No. 220



http://www.byui.edu/Presentations/Transcripts/Devotionals/2012_07_31_Esplin.htm

 

 

 

 

My dear brothers and sisters, welcome to campus at this beautiful time of year. I pray that the Holy Spirit will edify us this day as we discuss a topic of most singular importance. That topic is recognizing and increasing personal revelation.  The scriptures are replete with promises that God will answer our prayers. The Savior taught in the Sermon on the Mount, “Ask, and it shall be given you. Seek, and ye shall find. Knock, and it shall be opened unto you.”1 In the final stages of His ministry, He promised His disciples that “all things, whatsoever ye shall ask in prayer, believing, ye shall receive.”2

 

But what about those times when it seems as if the voice of the Holy Ghost is silent? Today I wish to speak to any of you who may feel your prayers have ever gone unanswered. First, let’s outline how we can recognize revelation, then we will discuss how to increase it.

 

Recognizing Personal Revelation

 

In Doctrine and Covenants section 6, the Lord teaches Oliver Cowdery that He has answered his prayers through the Spirit “as often as [he had] inquired,” even though Oliver may not have realized it.

 

“…blessed art thou for what thou hast done; for thou hast inquired of me, and behold, as often as thou hast inquired thou hast received instruction of my Spirit…Now I tell thee these things that thou mayest know that thou hast been enlightened by the Spirit of truth.3”


If we are striving to live righteously, it is possible we may be receiving promptings that we don’t recognize. President Lorenzo Snow explained:

 

[It is] the grand privilege of every Latter-day Saint . . . to have the manifestations of the spirit every day of our lives.4

 

The Lord wants each of us to recognize when the Spirit has enlightened our minds. But in order to do so, we need to be more familiar with the ways the Holy Ghost speaks to us. He can move us to action, give us peace, provide bright ideas, enhance our intelligence, magnify our talents and give us the very words we should speak or write.

 

As Sheri Dew has said:

 

“The Holy Ghost will show us everything we should do, [so] it only makes sense to learn how He communicates—or to learn the language of revelation. Our challenge is not getting the Lord to speak to us; our challenge is understanding what He has to say.5”

 

In order to better understand how God communicates with us, I invite you to consider with me four common types of personal revelation:

 

 

With the first type of revelation, divine promptings, the Spirit attempts to inspire us with divine communication that is unsolicited on our part. The second and third types of revelation, direct answers and confirming answers, occur when we initiate a two-way exchange by asking. The fourth type, ongoing promptings, is demonstrated when we request guidance that we don’t receive immediately.

 

Divine Promptings

 

Let’s first discuss divine promptings. We can receive promptings to stop by and visit a friend who is having a bad day, or take a different route to avoid an accident. We don’t always recognize that these ideas or feelings are coming from the Holy Spirit until after we act on them. However, if we recognize these divine directives for what they are, and thank the Lord for guidance, we will be better prepared to receive more in the future.

 

I learned a great lesson about recognizing and following divine promptings when my daughter, Zoe, and I were leaving Wal-Mart one evening.
